markdownRemark.excerpt: Is there a computer science topic more terrifying than Big O notation? Don‚Äôt let the name scare you, Big O notation is not a big deal. It‚Äôs very easy to‚Ä¶
markdownRemark.html:
Is there a computer science topic more terrifying than Big O notation? Don‚Äôt let the name scare you, Big O notation is not a big deal. It‚Äôs very easy to understand and you don‚Äôt need to be a math whiz to do so. Big O, Big Omega, or Œ©, and Big Theta, or Œò, are notations used to express the computational complexity of an algorithm. In this tutorial, you‚Äôll learn the difference between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta notations.

If you‚Äôre just joining us, you may want to start at the beginning with What is Big O Notation?.

Be O(#1). Grab your copy of The Little Book of Big O.

What is Asymptotic Computational Complexity?

Here‚Äôs the Wikipedia definition of asymptotic computational complexity:

In computational complexity theory, asymptotic computational complexity is the usage of asymptotic analysis for the estimation of computational complexity of algorithms and computational problems, commonly associated with the usage of the big O notation.

üò™

Right?

No wonder this stuff is hard to learn.

Let‚Äôs break this jargon down.

What is an Asymptote?

Here‚Äôs Wikipedia again, telling us that an asymptote of a curve is:

a line such that the distance between the curve and the line approaches zero as one or both of the x or y coordinates tends to infinity.

üòï

Yeah.

These definitions make an easy concept harder to understand.

We‚Äôre all visual learners, so let‚Äôs chart the following equation:

y = 1 / x

No matter how large (or small) the value of x, our curve will never touch the x or y axes.

Even if that number is Infinity.

üê¢üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Especially if that number is zero.

Why?

It‚Äôs mathematically impossible to divide by 0.

Division is another way to think about this. How many times can we divide one in half in before we reach zero?

There are infinite divisions!

Half of 1 is ¬Ω.

Half of ¬Ω is ¬º.

Half of ¬º is ‚Öõ.

Half of ‚Öõ is 1/16.

Half of 1/16 is‚Ä¶ you see where this is going.

With each division, our denominator increases by a power of 2.

We will never be able to halve something into nothing.

Unless it‚Äôs cake.

üç∞

In the chart above, the x and y axes are the asymptotes of the equation y = 1 / x. But any line can be an asymptote. We‚Äôre not limited to horizontal and vertical lines.

What is Asymptotic Analysis?

Let‚Äôs continue to digest these chewy definitions.

According to Wikipedia, asymptotic analysis is:

a method of describing limiting behavior.

What‚Äôs a limit?

In mathematics, a limit is the value that a function approaches as the input increases (or decreases).

Sounds a lot like an asymptote. So how do we analyze a function asymptotically?

If our function, f(x) is equal to x^2 + 2x, as x increases in value (and approaches infinity), 2x becomes insignificant compared to x^2.

We then simply say that f(x) is asymptotically equivalent to x^2.

What‚Äôs the Difference Between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta?

In Introduction to Algorithms, Cormen et al use Insertion Sort as an example to explain the difference between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta. We‚Äôll do the same here. Here‚Äôs an implementation of Insertion Sort in JavaScript:

const insertionSort = arr => {
 for (let i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) {
   let index = i;
   while (index > 0 && arr[index - 1] > arr[index]) {
     let temp = arr[index];
     arr[index] = arr[index - 1];
     arr[index - 1] = temp;
     index = index - 1;
   }
 }
 return arr;
}

And here‚Äôs a quick refresher (or explainer) on Insertion Sort:

  • We iterate over the entire array.

  • For each element in the array, we check:

    • If the value of the index is greater than 1

    • If the element preceding the index is greater than the index itself

  • If both conditions are met, we swap them

What is Big O?

Big O describes the upper bound of an algorithm.

Using our Insertion Sort example, the rate of growth of our algorithm is at most quadratic, or O(n^2).

This is why, for us, as developers and practitioners, we are primarily concerned with Big O.

We want to know just how poorly an algorithm might perform.

To say that the Big O of Insertion Sort is O(n^2) doesn‚Äôt mean that Insertion Sort will always be O(n^2). The actual runtime will vary based on the input. What we are saying is that, in a worst case scenario, this is the upper bound of the performance of Insertion Sort.

Knowing this, we then need to ask ourselves the following questions:

  • Are we okay with this?

  • Can we do better?

What is Big Omega?

Big Omega describes the lower bound of an algorithm.

Using our Insertion Sort example, if the input is already sorted, then the rate of growth of our algorithm is at least linear, or Œ©(n).

If only life always handed us sorted arrays. üåº

We can also think of this as our best-case scenario.

What is Big Theta?

Big Theta describes the tight bound of an algorithm, it‚Äôs limit from above and below.

Using our Insertion Sort example, we know that the rate of growth is at most O(n^2) and at least Œ©(n).

But Big Theta will change with our inputs. Returning to our Insertion Sort example, in a best case scenario, Big Theta is n, but in a worst case scenario, Big Theta is n^2. To say that Insertion Sort is Œò(n) or Œò(n^2) is incorrect as both of these imply that Insertion Sort will always run at either n or n^2.

So what use is Big Theta?

Big Theta is often used to describe the average, or expected, case for an algorithm. This isn‚Äôt exactly true, but it‚Äôs a useful shorthand.

So for Insertion Sort, the average case for Big Theta is n^2.

So What‚Äôs the Difference Between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta?

We can think of Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta like conditional operators:

  • Big O is like <=, meaning the rate of growth of an algorithm is less than or equal to a specific value, e.g: f(x) <= O(n^2)

  • Big Omega is like >=, meaning the rate of growth is greater than or equal to a specified value, e.g: f(x) >= Œ©(n).

  • Big Theta is like ==, meaning the rate of growth is equal to a specified value, e.g: f(x) = Œò(n^2).

But if we needed to make a blanket statement for all cases, we would use Big O, and, for example, say that Insertion Sort is O(n^2).

Best Case, Worst Case, and Expected Case

What is the relationship between best case/worst case/expected case and Big O/Big Omega/Big Theta?

There isn‚Äôt one.

Equivalencies are often made between Big O and worst case, Big Omega and best case, and Big Theta and average case, but we can speak of best, worst, and average for each of these notations.

For example, each of the following statements are true:

  • Insertion Sort‚Äôs worst case rate of growth is at most O(n^2)

  • Insertion Sort‚Äôs worst case rate of growth is at least Œ©(n)

  • Insertion Sort‚Äôs worst case rate of growth is exactly Œò(n^2)

Big O, Big Omega, Big Theta, Big Sigh!

In this tutorial, you learned the difference between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta notations.

frontmatter.title: What‚Äôs the Difference Between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta?
frontmatter.description: Big O is only one of many notations for analyzing the complexity of algorithms. In this tutorial, you‚Äôll learn the difference between Big O, Big Omega, and Big Theta notations.
